Award.AwardTitle: Building a Plan to Improve the Mathematics and Science Teaching Workforce in North Georgia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Noyce Capacity Building Project will bring together faculty and staff from the University of Georgia (UGA) and local educators to develop plans to recruit, train, and support more qualified secondary mathematics and science teachers in Northeast Georgia. The plan represents a first step in addressing the shortage of qualified STEM teachers in the region. The overall motivational goal of the project team is to increase STEM talent in the region's workforce by better preparing teachers to work with diverse and under-represented students.

To develop the recruitment, preparation, and support plans, the PI and Co-PI will create two teams, the Core and Advisory Teams, from the University of Georgia community. Together these teams will work to 1) assess the need for science and mathematics teachers in the region; 2) determine if STEM professionals exist in the community who could potentially enter the teaching workforce; 3) determine how well University of Georgia science and mathematics teacher preparation programs prepare and support students to meet national and state standards; and 4) strengthen ties between University of Georgia education and STEM faculty and staff. The collected data will inform the emerging plan, which will be written by the Core Team and critiqued by the Advisory Team. The final plan will be based on a process of evidence-based decision making, which will be shared with other institutions. With it in hand, the Core Team will be able to efficiently work towards increasing the number of high-quality secondary mathematics and science teachers produced at UGA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes - Building a Plan to Improve the Mathematics and Science Teaching Workforce in North Georgia

This project, which is titled 'Georgia Educators in Mathematics and Science (GEMS),'  is a Noyce Capacity Building project that brought together faculty from the Franklin College of Arts and Sciences and the College of Education to assess the number of secondary mathematics and science teachers in the region, and to evaluate the recruitment and preparation of secondary mathematics and science teachers at the University of Georgia. This team also examined the support that was provided to newly graduated secondary mathematics and science teachers from the University of Georgia. From this project, which studied our recruitment and preparation of secondary mathematics and science teachers for schools in Northeast Georgia, we did collect enough data to submit a Noyce Track 1 proposal.

The intellectual merit of this project is based in the evidence-based conclusions that were a result of the assessment of the shortage of mathematics and science teachers in the region, an analysis of the recruitment and preparation of mathematics and science teachers, and the support provided to newly graduated mathematics and science teachers from the University of Georgia. We specifically found that: schools in Northeast Georgia have a need for additional secondary mathematics and science teachers, there is a need to develop new recruitment approaches at the University of Georgia, and teachers in the University of Georgia mathematics and science teacher education program could further develop their abilities to teach all students.

The broader impacts of this project pertain to the submission of a Noyce Track 1 grant, which can potentially increase in the number of secondary mathematics and science teachers that will work in Northeast Georgia. In addition, the broader impacts of this project have resulted in an increased awareness of the role of STEM faculty in recruiting and preparing secondary science and mathematics teachers. Overtime, this project has the potential to increase the STEM talent in Georgia by encouraging a diverse population of students to participate in STEM fields.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.
